TopicTitle: Devnote Tuesdays: The Temporary "First Contract Edition" Thread

Articles.Content:
More crashes.

No really there's no in-game benefit to 64 bits. If it had multithreading that'd be a whole different story. But the only actual real benefit is you're helping test the 64 bit version in a stock game - something that most people won't do considering the whole point is to add tons of mods. It's possible that crashes in your game are far more beneficial to Squad than most any other crashes in most any other installs.

Preliminary (albeit bootleg) testing results from the KSP 64bits on Windows (this time, it's not a request) thread proves your statement is most likely incorrect. Not to hype it up too much, but, many reported drastic improvements in performance.

Edited June 26, 2014 by Apollyon

Which of course means if resources are ever implemented in the future, it is clearly a sign that Squad only gets their ideas from modders and never start exploring things like 64 bit until someone makes a barely stable version of it despite the fact that they've basically said for quite a while that they have been looking at the possibility of 64 bit for a while.

edit: yes, i'm being sarcastic

I get the sarcasm but I don't get all the all the comments about resource system being only in the realm of mods. All the resource mods I have seen utilize the resource system that SQUAD put in the game back in 0.20?- 0.21? In fact the only thing I can think of that SQUAD plans to add to the game that was not in the original plan is multiplayer. (The Nasa thing is kinda that way too but that is more like a special ED feature than anything else) In any case just scratching my head in confusion:confused:.

Preliminary (albeit bootleg) testing results from the KSP 64bits on Windows (this time, it's not a request) thread proves your statement is most likely incorrect. Not to hype it up too much, but, many reported drastic improvements in performance.

That's good! I'm happy to be wrong in this instance.

For me personally, I noticed no speedup on a stock install with that (albeit hacked together) setup, and when I stated adding mods my game got so crashy I gave up. I haven't really followed it in depth since then, except with the hope for what eventually happened far quicker than I ever expected.

I get the sarcasm but I don't get all the all the comments about resource system being only in the realm of mods. All the resource mods I have seen utilize the resource system that SQUAD put in the game back in 0.20?- 0.21?

That resource system that you mention was actually designed at a time when the devs intended to use it as a foundation for a higher level system, creating a more complicated/realistic version of Kethane. They even posted a huge chart showing a preliminary plan for each raw resource, what part(s) would "mine" it, what part(s) could process it into intermediate or final results, etc. It hinted at life support, ISRU, and off-world-manufacturing, getting much of the player base excited and wound up.

As they worked on implementing it, the devs realized that their system was overly complicated, and worse, didn't seem to be much fun, just another hoop to jump through. So it got simplified, and then eventually cancelled, though the decision to cancel it was probably made a few months before it was announced to the player base. A not-insignificant fraction of that player base got rather upset over this, and some fraction of those people trot it out again whenever they feel insecure about future development, or in some cases, just because they feel slighted.

While I've said it's not the decision I would have made, I can understand why they canned a feature that was not meeting their expectations and standards.

Preliminary (albeit bootleg) testing results from the KSP 64bits on Windows (this time, it's not a request) thread proves your statement is most likely incorrect. Not to hype it up too much, but, many reported drastic improvements in performance.

That might be overstating it. There are more people that have not noticed a difference than those that have. It's possible that there will be a benefit, but don't count on it.

That might be overstating it. There are more people that have not noticed a difference than those that have. It's possible that there will be a benefit, but don't count on it.

I would love to test it out myself, but 64bit KSP apparently has no intention of working for me. In lieu of that we can rely on the results from Franklin, who has run the only direct comparison of 32bit vs 64bit KSP on Windows that I've seen. They show basically no difference in performance.

It's also worth noting that some of the difference that people observe may be from re-installing KSP or deleting and re-installing mods. There can be a fairly significant impact on performance in some cases just by doing these things.

Edited June 26, 2014 by DMagic

That resource system that you mention was actually designed at a time when the devs intended to use it as a foundation for a higher level system, creating a more complicated/realistic version of Kethane. They even posted a huge chart showing a preliminary plan for each raw resource, what part(s) would "mine" it, what part(s) could process it into intermediate or final results, etc. It hinted at life support, ISRU, and off-world-manufacturing, getting much of the player base excited and wound up.

As they worked on implementing it, the devs realized that their system was overly complicated, and worse, didn't seem to be much fun, just another hoop to jump through. So it got simplified, and then eventually cancelled, though the decision to cancel it was probably made a few months before it was announced to the player base. A not-insignificant fraction of that player base got rather upset over this, and some fraction of those people trot it out again whenever they feel insecure about future development, or in some cases, just because they feel slighted.

While I've said it's not the decision I would have made, I can understand why they canned a feature that was not meeting their expectations and standards.

Hmm.. AH yes I remember all that now. I also have been playing long enough to remember talk of destroyable building and such that you had to pay to repair if you damaged them. Not sure if any of that is going to happen now or not. To be sure I am not sure if I care. I love KSP, It is the best game I have played ever ( I thought so when I started playing at update 0.15 and still do) and considering I have been playing video games since 1984 that says a lot (I Hope). I do wish people would try to remember that the game is still in development even if it is nearly finished and I think it has gone far beyond the creators wildest dreams. I am a little bummed that there wont be a stock resource system. But if it can not be integrated effectively it is probably best to leave it as a mod for those of us who are more die hard. I would rather they spent their time optimizing the game to work better faster with less resources. THough my PC was top end 7 years ago it is definitely showing its age now and frankly I can't afford a new PC right now so the more efficiently KSP runs the more I can do with it.

The "Can Do!" spirit that all Kerbals share inspired me to this title idea for .24:

Budget Projected, Contract Accepted!

Let's keep the positive energy flowing!

64-bit. 8go of RAM. Dreams coming true.

Keep the flow of good work going, squad's guÃƒÂ¯ses.

My suggestions:

-KSP should have built in asset management with real time loading/unloading of resources (textures primarily).

-KSP needs an improved texture look up system. Allow us in our Configs to set specifically the location of the texture used by the part. This would allow us to have multiple parts use a single large texture map. For an example of this, see my Phase II satellite parts mod which has all the parts use a single texture for external and a single texture for internal.

+1. I love KSP, and it's fantastic what modders have been able to do with it, but this is clearly the number 1 back-end issue with the game. Moving to 64-bit might allow you to use more RAM, but it's silly that the game requires so much RAM in the first place. Dynamically loading resources would make load-times and screen-switching much quicker, and would kill the RAM issue for good, even without 64-bit support.

Dynamically loading resources would make load-times and screen-switching much quicker, and would kill the RAM issue for good, even without 64-bit support.

Initial load time? Sure, that would be faster. There's no way scene switching would be faster if it has to load everything for the next scene from disk. Reading assets from disk will always* be slower than from RAM. *(Except in cases where active memory and storage memory are the same, or some other weird situations that generally don't apply to KSP.)

I do agree that dynamic asset loading would fix the RAM issue, and to me that outweighs the rest.

Does anyone know if front-loading assets is a Unity thing? Or is it something KSP does deliberately?

WOOT! Go Squad, it looks like delaying the release of 0.24 was an awesome decision, I can't wait to try out the official 64 bit version!

WAT, 64 bit version? HOOHAH!

I would love to test it out myself, but 64bit KSP apparently has no intention of working for me. In lieu of that we can rely on the results from Franklin, who has run the only direct comparison of 32bit vs 64bit KSP on Windows that I've seen. They show basically no difference in performance.

It's also worth noting that some of the difference that people observe may be from re-installing KSP or deleting and re-installing mods. There can be a fairly significant impact on performance in some cases just by doing these things.

Maybe if you have a really narrow view of the word "performance". It's not always about Frames per Second you know.

Good timing!

Looks like the current season of Elite: Dangerous over on Sim Gamer TV is going to wrap until next update. So - back to KSP - my very first (and still the best) YouTube game! Looking forward to Let's Play Kerbal Space Program Career Mode, Season 0.24!

Why on Kerbin would anyone think that Squad would try to charge for this? They've stated quite clearly that the only thing that would be considered an expansion would be content developed after the game goes gold.

Obviously they have been brainwashed by modern, greedy, evil game corporations (yes, that looks positively sarcastic, but I mean every word of it) into thinking that just about any way of screwing their player base over is perfectly okay and I've even seen people actively arguing that it's the best thing for everyone. It makes me shudder because of the way the game industry's going.

Back in the day, if there was an update to the game in order to fix stuff with new drivers or whatever, it was a given that it should be free. We called them patches. Now, if the developers have so much as sneezed at the code, we should consider ourselves lucky if it's not a DLC. Back in the day, if we wanted to play something on our own, i.e. single player, we bought the game and installed it and started playing. Now we should consider ourselves lucky if the servers that we constantly have to be connected to in order to play, quite alone, on our own, are up and running, ready to validate your credit card and facebook account if you want to so much as watch the opening cinematic. Back in the day, if a game had multiplayer, it meant that two people who had the game could play the game together, linking their computers and being in the same game environment. When multiplayer was mentioned for KSP, the assumption was that it would be an MMO-like thing where people would be forced to do all kinds of MMO-y things with other people they don't want to play with, like a completely different game - and again, with a subscription. What has gaming come to? Where are all the good ole' attitudes towards the player base? The fun and warmth in gaming? When did the only priority become creating a profitable business model, rather than a kick-ass game?

Yes, this turned out to be a grandpa rant (although I'm not even 30), but if you bear with me, I'll tell you where the good ole' attitudes are, where the warmth in gaming is, and where the will to create a kick-ass game is a priority: It's alive and kicking at SQUAD! It's one of the reasons I've become a fan of SQUAD; they give me a warm, fuzzy feeling of nostalgia, however with a new game, but the way they used to make them. No constant validation servers, no facebook log-in, no small mountain of DLC's before the game is in a playable state, no forced MMO modes. It really shines through that it's a game about sending your toy-soldiers-turned-aliens into the space and not about bleeding a certain gaming demographic dry of their money. The football mod just proves that point: Such a warm, whimsical boon to the players, it's really heart-warming.

Unfortunately, I haven't had time to play anything at all lately, but I'm really looking forward to finding some time later in the summer to restart my KSP career and try it with funds and contracts and everything that's new and awesome in 0.24! In fact, even though I haven't actually had time to play it at all lately, I always look forward to Devnote Wednesdays so that I can be even more hyped for when I find the time to play again

What has gaming come to? Where are all the good ole' attitudes towards the player base? The fun and warmth in gaming? When did the only priority become creating a profitable business model, rather than a kick-ass game?

You clearly missed the "insert a quarter to continue" days. Or the legion of crap games that came out with the Atari 2500. Or the price fixing schemes that Nintendo forced on 3rd party developers for the NES. Or having to pay for 5 1/4" floppies at your local PC shop that had copies of game demos they'd downloaded for free (at 2400 bps) from a BBS. Or when a game publisher would charge you full price for a replacement set of floppies when one of them stopped working. Or etc etc. Back "in the day" there were no patches: you got what came in the box. If it was buggy, sometimes the developer would fix it, but you'd have to buy a new box to get the fixes. Back in the day, there were games that required you to e-mail the developer for an activation code.

There was no magical golden age of rainbows and ponies when game devs worked on games as a service to humanity, expecting to eat the goodwill of their fellow citizens and be sheltered by the joy they gave the children. Video games have always, always been plagued by DRM, markets flooded with crap-ware, profiteers looking to monetize everything, pay-for extra content, bad customer service, etc. Video game makers have always needed to eat.

I'd actually say that now, right now, is the real golden age of video games, particularly as consumers. There are more indie developers than ever, with great ideas exploding all over the place. You can purchase (humble) bundles of many extremely high-quality games (DRM free) for $1. Fan feedback and modding communities have taken gaming places that were unimaginable 20 or even 10 years ago. GOG and similar sites are making older (and newer) games easy-to-buy and easy-to-install. (Have you ever wrestled with autoexec.bat, trying to get your memory settings just right so that $50 game you purchased the night before will load up?) Multiplayer is easier and huger than it's ever been. (Most consumer games 'in the day' were either 2-player over a modem, used hot-seat play, or were play-by-email.) Steam makes maintaining an absolutely huge library of video games that I've bought over a decade (mostly for very cheap prices) completely painless; no bookshelves used up; no compatibility problems with new OS releases; no lost discs. There are multiple huge conventions throughout the year geared specifically to video games and video game culture. Video games are a bigger industry than the movies.

I have no desire to go back to the 'good old days'. I like gaming where it is right now.
I believe the word pwnage applies to the above reply.

Yes, this turned out to be a grandpa rant (although I'm not even 30)

Yet you felt qualified to make such a comment? Rants such as these don't tend to pan out too well if you haven't been alive long enough to have actually seen the old days. Your time scale is too small and experience too incomplete.
Don't derail the thread guys

I would have to say both sides had some very good points.

I think iMAniaC spoke very well to SQUADS excellent and exemplary customer service, support, cooperation, and fair play. I also think that he address fairly not so much the Game industry as a whole but how many of the very largest and most popular game companies treat their customers. I think also that PC Gaming has seen a dramatic shift from its early days in the 90s where the biggest and best game makers treated their customers similarly to how SQUAD treats us.

However Mr Shifty also is correct in saying there were a lot of really crummy companies out there and some of them still survive today especially in the game system platforms.

I would say that in PC gaming at least the big companies most closely reflect iMAniaC's view and the small independent game makers most closely reflect Mr Shifty's view of the gaming world. Thank goodness SQUAD fair's well in both views

*Lots of good points*

Yes, I'll freely admit that my rant wasn't very objective, and that it completely ignores everything that's good about today's gaming. If it would've been objective with well-weighed arguments, I wouldn't call it a rant But it does reflect my feelings about the standards in the game industry and that although most things have gotten better, I feel that something has also been lost. mcirish3 sums it up pretty well, I think.

I'm sorry about derailing the thread. Please don't continue to derail it on my account.
Is there going to be any SPECIFIC details about this update before it is released? Video? Thanks!
Squad don't like to give too much detail in case a feature fails to pass testing and has to be pulled or changed until the next release.

OHMYGOD THIS FORUM IS NOT BLOCKED ON MY WORKPLACE'S FIREWALL.

*ahem*

"Titans of Industry". That sounds so goddamned badass.

On a side note, a feature I'd really like to see on a future update is a way to organize my parts, sort them various ways, hide the ones i never use, this kind of stuff. There are some mods for that, but I'm personally tired of installing mods that overlay their own UI, I'd rather have something that worked within the same tabs and pages as stock game uses for parts.

That said, it is already a great game the way it is, last update got me really happy with the optimizations, I'm eager for the 64 version. And contracts, don't even get me started on those! MCE is an awesome mod for that, I use it and love it, but, like I said before, I'd rather have stuff integrated into the existing UI; plus my 30-something installed mods are beginning to lag my laptop... quite a bit. BUT I CAN'T LET GO OF THEM Here I go, beginning career mode from scratch again. Will I ever get to Jool before I ditch my efforts over and over?

I know it's not needed, but... you know... slight OCD and stuff.

Can't wait till the 64-bit comes out.Till then i just going to say

"64 64 have you hear ,64 64 yes I have ksp in 64-bit."(imagine the theme of lone ranger playing with it)
